abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though institutional
            development impacts are only modest. Several lessons are
            drawn from the project, as follows. Although the initial
            quality of engineering designs lacked coordination and
            quality of site investigations, experienced consultants, and
            appropriate supervision by line ministries and implementing
            agencies, currently, international experience is extensively
            used through modern design, and survey techniques. This
            dramatically reduced the need for roads redesign, and
            accelerated implementation. Nonetheless, the contract
            management framework did not work as envisaged: the dual
            nature of responsibilities among implementing agencies,
            hampered coordination, which lead to delays affecting
            contract management. However, corrective action was taken,
            by assigning full responsibility to the National Highways
            Authority, but for the long run, alternative arrangements
            will have to be developed with clear responsibilities.
            Regarding procurement, as outlined above, and in addition to
            a weak knowledge of Bank's guidelines, disagreements,
            notwithstanding, were conducive to the adjustment of
            standard contract documents, according to India's
            specific conditions. Regrettably, the absence of
            environmental assessments (EAs), and resettlement action
            plans (RAPs) at the start of the project, aggravated by no
            capacity training in environmental issues, nor baseline
            surveys prior to displacement of affected people, delayed
            implementation; rather, the already, existing standard
            practice should have been enforced, by implementing early
            on, both an EA and RAP to ensure the adequate targeted
            assistance. Further lessons reinforce the need to build
            client ownership, enhance donor coordination, and establish
            the necessary readiness for project implementation at
            approval time.

18153442.trustfund: TF034775-INDIA - NATIONAL HIGHWAYS,TF026215-FINANCING OF AUSAID SECONDMENTS,TF036231-INDIA - NATIONAL HIGHWAYS
18153442.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project are to:
            (i) modernize key sections of the national highway network;
            (ii) promote improvements in:  road engineering and
            construction; network management; and contract management;
            and (iii) reconstruct selected flood damaged bridges in the
            State of Orissa.  The project includes:  (a) modernization
            of six sections, about 290 kilometers, of heavily trafficked
            and congested national highways in Haryana, Madhya Pradesh,
            Maharashtra, Orissa, Punjab and West Bengal; (b) equipment
            for monitoring and management of the national highway
            network; (c) institutional strengthening including:  (i)
            training of the Ministry of Surface Transport (MOST) and the
            Public Works Department staff for works supervision; (ii)
            technical assistance to MOST; and (d) studies to prepare
            follow-up projects.  Reconstruction of six bridges in Ganjam
            District in Orissa is also included in this project.
